main.subhed: Follow a tiny snowflake as it makes its way to a sugarbeet field in the pandhandle of Nebraska.

snow.subhed: It all begins up high, where snow piles in sheets, in waves, in avalanche cascades in Colorado’s Rocky Mountains.

grafs.graf: The sharp peaks of the Nokhu Crags emerge slowly and gracefully above a dark ridge of pine on the steep climb to Lake Agnes. The trail ends on a rocky outcropping above a lake of black glass, where the sides of snowy mountains slide down to the shore. Winter winds whip around this remote alpine spot, near the headwaters of the North Platte River.

As it has for centuries, water arrives annually to these mountains as snow and ice, collecting at high elevations to wait for spring’s warmth. In the arid west, the majority of the water that fills streams and rivers comes from winter snowpack. Every year, farmers, raft guides, conservationists, fishermen, city planners and others wait anxiously to see what winter will bring.
The answer is the difference between a good year and a bad one. Water is the life and livelihood of downstream users, and it all starts high in the mountains with a single snowflake.

Ski fanatics know exactly how much fresh powder each storm brings to their mountains. But others track that data, too. For the last 100 years, January is when the annual cycle of water management begins, as hydrologists answer a critical question: how much water is up there this year?

Mage Hultstrand glides through deep snow, approaching a collection of silvery devices coated in icy powder. “We measure the water content of the snow here,” Hultstrand said. She’s a hydrologist with the Natural Resources Conservation Service’s snow survey program in Denver. Today she’s at the Joe Wright SNOTEL site in the Cache la Poudre drainage, part of the South Platte River Basin.

“This is the headwater state, so this is where all of your water is coming from,” Hultstrand said, “with the exception of whatever precipitation is received in spring and summer. But really, this is the bulk of it.”

The SNOTEL system has been in place for decades, transmitting data back to centralized offices where it’s assessed and compiled into public reports. But it complements an even older method of data collection: manual snow surveys. From January through May, teams go out to specific locations--the same ones year after year--to collect information about snowpack. They ski or snowshoe through forests heavy with snow to the more remote sites, weathering sleet, blizzards or ice storms.
A University of Nevada professor named Frank Church pioneered the system of snow surveying in 1905.

“He wanted to find a better way of forecasting runoff,” Matt Hoobler said. And his method proved durable: during the last century, things haven’t changed much. Hoobler is a snow surveyor with the Wyoming State Engineer's Office who conducts manual surveys each winter. “The basic premise of filling a tube full of snow and weighing it...we do something very similar today,” Hoobler said.

Near the summit of Interstate 80 in southeastern Wyoming, weak sunlight makes its way through the thin air to where Hoobler is taking a core sample of the snowpack. He carefully holds a specially calibrated cylinder, which measures snow depth, weight, and density, then drops it vertically into the snow, twists it, and pulls it back out to analyze.
“Water content at this site is 5.5 inches,” Hoobler said. “That means if this snow was to melt instantaneously, there’d be 5.5 inches of water sitting in this meadow.”
“The main reason we’re up here for snow survey is for river forecasting. In other words, once it all turns to water, how much water is going to exist in our rivers and our reservoirs,” Hoobler said.

Each year surveyors add new data to the collection, validating the record and improving accuracy. The field data coming in from snow surveys and SNOTEL sites, including precipitation, is compiled into monthly stream flow forecasts for the spring and summer. That information is critical to many diverse downstream users, especially farmers who rely on irrigation water.

Basin-wide water users generally start to make decisions based upon the April 1st report. Knowing if the water supply is above or below average can determine a boom or bust year for crops, if rancher have to sell their cows, if migrating birds will have adequate nesting habitat, if raft guides will have summer employment.

“Society depends on water -- whether it’s growing the crops we’re going to eat or producing hydroelectric power. 50 to 80 percent of flows of North Platte River depend on this white stuff – snow,” Hoobler said.

Because quantity and quality of snowpack is the source of water for so many uses, a dry year can cause a cascade of impacts, flowing all the way down to a farmer’s beet crop in the Nebraska panhandle. The past three years have seen two snowpack extremes: the huge water year of 2011 followed by 2012, the hottest and driest on record for many places in the intermountain west and plains. 2013 remained drier than average, but 2014 has once again proven to be a big water year in the mountains. That wide variability, Hoobler said, is “what makes farmers pray for rain and snow.”

It’s generally hard for climatologists to predict what kind of a year it will be for snowpack, though global climate events like El Nino and La Nina often impact western weather. But snow accumulation is only one part of the story, since the climate of the region matters too. In 2012, some farmers ran out of their river irrigation water partway through the season, even as scorching temperatures continued and rain never came. Those that could drew heavily from the aquifer, pumping groundwater up to their fields when river water ran out. This year, irrigation demands were slow to start because of a cool, wet spring. Combined with a high snowpack runoff season, reservoirs along the North Platte River had time to fill, banking water for another dry year in the future.

As winter relaxes into spring, that massive quantity of water stored high in the mountains begins to melt and make its way into streams and rivers, where it is channeled through dams and reservoirs to feed crops. The North Platte River starts to creep north from Colorado into Wyoming, where it meets the first of several stops along the way to a farmer’s field.

storage.subhed: Once it descends from the mountains, this valuable resource meets human intervention, carefully directed downstream through an intricate system of dams and reservoirs.

grafs.graf: Born in the high reaches of the Rocky Mountains, the headwaters of the North Platte River trickle down in ice-cold tributaries to form a channel that winds across the Wyoming-Colorado state line. The river runs free across yellow-brown sagebrush steppe until it backs up behind Seminoe, the first of several dams north of Sinclair, Wyo.
Until this point the river has been mostly wild and untamed. Here the water intersects the course of westward expansion and the demands of humans who bent waterways to their will.

The 100th meridian is often considered a dividing line between the western and eastern United States. As settlers learned, rainfall averages less than 20 inches a year west of this line; not a sustainable source of water for agriculture and industry. But snow collected in the mountains each winter, melting into torrential, sometimes flooding, rivers in the spring. And western pioneers were nothing if not enterprising. Early settlers capitalized on this resource by building irrigation systems to divert high spring runoff that would last through early summer. But each year the water would run out, abandoning crops and residents to the exactitudes of the sun and wind during the hottest time of the year. Thus began the concept of “reclaiming” western lands: restructuring natural water systems for human use through massive, federally-sponsored irrigation projects.

Driven by growing public pressure from westerners, in the late 1800s, Congress passed a series of acts to encourage and study the development of irrigation in the west. But it wasn’t until President Theodore Roosevelt signed the Reclamation Act in 1902 that the federal government seriously invested in western irrigation projects. Then the newly-minted U.S. Reclamation Service began to build dams and reservoirs to store water and essentially “re-time” high spring flows to deliver a steady water supply to agricultural users and municipalities throughout the year. They authorized 25 projects between 1903 and 1906.

The second of these projects was Pathfinder Dam, named in honor of one of the West’s most intrepid explorers, John C. Fremont. Situated just below where the Sweetwater River flows into the North Platte River, the site is remote, even today. And even by today’s standards, the 214 foot-high dam and its complementary dike were an enormous undertaking. Machinery had to be hauled in from Casper, 47 miles to the north. Granite quarried from local hills was hewn into huge blocks to create the arch-style structure, 97 feet thick at the base narrowing to a mere 11 feet at the top. The top spans the girth of Fremont Canyon, offering dramatic views down steep sides to the river below. To the south, more than one million acre-feet of mountain snowmelt can collect in Pathfinder Reservoir. After five long years of construction, it was completed in 1909.

Pathfinder was the first major piece of the North Platte Project, one of several huge irrigation projects that determined the history of the American West by providing a reliable water supply to dry agricultural lands, industries and burgeoning cities. Today the project provides water to around 335,000 acres in eastern Wyoming and western Nebraska.

As the twentieth century progressed, more water rights were acquired on the North Platte River. Dams, reservoirs and power plants were built to generate hydroelectric power and supply water for irrigated land north of Casper and for the Missouri River Basin, and a complex system of water management emerged.

Water rights west of the Missouri River generally follow the Prior Appropriation Doctrine, commonly explained as “first in time, first in right.” But from the beginning of the Bureau of Reclamation’s history, navigating myriad water rights has been a challenging yet critical piece of the puzzle.

As North Platte River water moves from Colorado all the way down to fields in Nebraska, it’s carefully accounted for and divvyed up. Many interests have a share in it: farmers and ranchers to cities to even a few birds and fish, federally protected under the 1973 Endangered Species Act. In the Plains and West, few issues are as contentious as water, and few require such an arsenal of lawyers.
The river has been subject to a few different lawsuits since the North Platte Project was built. In 1934 Nebraska sued Wyoming over the amount of North Platte River it water it received.

“It’s basic water history in the West,” says Matt Hoobler with the Wyoming State Engineer’s Office. “It doesn’t matter if you’re Kansas to Colorado, or California to Colorado or California to Wyoming, it doesn’t matter. Downstream states look upstream for more water.”

The ruling fell in favor of Nebraska, splitting the water 75 percent/25 percent between it and Wyoming, respectively, because of the amount of land under agricultural production. That agreement still holds today.

On the North Platte system, all of these complicated agreements and allotments are controlled from one central place, the Bureau of Reclamation’s Wyoming Area Office in Casper. On a visit one recent morning, the drab official-looking building matched the overcast sky.

Lyle Myler is the deputy area manager for the office, which operates east of the Continental Divide. Each year, Myler’s office depends upon the snowpack data gathered by the Natural Conservation Resource Service and Wyoming State Engineer’s Office to make judgments based on how much water will be coming down from the mountains.

“We do a forecast beginning February 1st that gives an estimate of the volume of water that we think we’re going to get in four months. That gives us a feel for how we start positioning water in the reservoirs,” says Myler. Tall, with an easy smile and voice that carries just a hint of drawl, Myler is a veteran water manager. He’s been with the office for 24 years and can rattle off facts and figures from any of their systems with ease.

“We keep track of the storage we deliver out and how much of that water is Glendo storage water, how much is Kendrick water, how much is North Platte storage,” says Myler. “The thing that’s difficult to judge is if you get a big rain event, how is that going to affect the volume that comes in?  So, it keeps us busy.”

In a small office inside the building, highly-trained operators sit in front of multiple computer screens, controlling water in three different states: Wyoming, Colorado and Montana. They work around the clock year-round, serving as the operators, security, and emergency personnel for all the dams and reservoirs, and coordinating power supply with the Western Area Power Administration. They follow target flow orders from the three different state water offices, says Ray Balerio, control room supervisor. Operators are always scanning their water and data logs, especially at volatile locations, continuously make minor adjustments across the system to keep them on track.

It is amazing with the push of a button we can release so much water. Just by selecting a power plant and pushing a button,” says Balerio. In his 25 years at the office, he’s seen all kinds of events, and laughs when asked which is easier: responding to droughts and floods, saying both often prove challenging.

“When you have a lot of water everything’s running full bore, everything’s going out full maximum so you don’t have a lot of changes. But during the drought season you’re trying to conserve water so you’re watching every drop so you have a lot of changes which is really stressful because you may be doing 15 changes every two hours,” says Balerio.

Guernsey Reservoir, completed in 1927, is also part of the North Platte Project. It sits at the very end of the chain of seven dams and reservoirs carrying water through eastern Wyoming, the last in line to release water to the east. On this river system the irrigation season runs May 1st through September 30th, at which point the Bureau of Reclamation shuts the gates at Guernsey, holding back the rest of the water until the following year.

“This year we had a good run-off season,” says Myler, with more than one million acre feet coming into the upper river system from snow melt runoff and rain. On average, it’s about 700,000 acre-feet. “The two previous years [2013 and 2012] saw well-below average inflows so the supply was quite depleted. It took a big amount of water to fill it up, but we got it full.” Those years offered a striking contrast to the huge water year of 2011, when the system received more than two million acre-feet of water.

Like most other western river basins, the accounting and managing of water on the North Platte River is complex. And like most other river basins, the water flowing through the complicated network is vital to the survival of ranchers, farmers, cities and wildlife downstream.

The North Platte Project embodies the story of the settling of the American West. Today, during an average water year, Bureau of Reclamation projects deliver water to roughly one-third of the irrigated acreage and people in western states. Without “reclaiming” or bringing western watersheds under human control, nothing in the arid west would be the same; agriculture, industry, cities and towns.

field.subhed: Mountain snowmelt arrives onto the plains to water thirsty fields, supporting the economy of an entire region.

grafs.graf: “I’ll be waiting for you at seven, in my blue truck in the driveway,” instructed the kind yet gruff voice of Bob Busch on the phone. He’s prompt, and expects the same from visitors. Just past seven the next day, he directed the way to one of his sugar beet fields along the Gering/Fort Laramie Irrigation District’s canal in the cool morning breeze.

Wearing faded denim overalls, a toothy smile and a Kelly Bean Co. mesh hat, Busch watched his grandson and a farm hand “move water” with an approving gaze. He knows this process well. A third-generation farmer in the Nebraska panhandle, Busch has spent nearly all of his 77 years on the same patch of land outside of Gering. After a short stint at college, he took over farming the family property from his father in 1959.
“I dearly love farming,” Busch said. “I don’t like some of the adversity we have. Weather… You’d get a hail storm, oh, mercy. You’d be done. But farming’s my life and always has been.”

Busch’s son Kendall, 52, now runs the operation, more than 1,000 acres of corn, sugar beets, dry edible beans and alfalfa. They still use flood or furrow irrigation, an older method than ?? that requires a lot of early summer mornings.

After setting the siphon tubes, they’ll let the water flow across this field for 24 hours before moving it (what - the water or the tubes or the process?)again tomorrow morning. They do this throughout the irrigation season, from May through September, making the most of their water.
“Our [operation] is very labor intense. It takes a lot of manpower and a lot of time,” Kendall Busch said.
